And in a way so that it benefits her financially. She has partnered with some stores and cafes so that she will supply them with her own made "pelmeni" (dumplings with filling). Besides that she was also able to find clients to purchase noodles for lagman (a dish consisting of long noodles, meat and vegetables), which Raisa will also make herself. For Raisa this extra business has turned out to be a really good thing. Because she does not need to go anywhere. She completes all her orders from home and this is why this job does not wear her out. Besides that Raisa had a few debts. The salary of a cook in cafe alone was not enough to pay off her debts all at once. But after she has started her own business it did not take very much for her to pay off all of her debts. Only a few hours of work during the weekends brings Raisa around 3,000 soms monthly. Many people have to work a whole month for this money. Right now Raisa decided to ask for a loan to buy two bags of flour, meat for the filling and use the remainder of the loan to pay her son's tuition. Raisa has four partners in her group: Nasykat is twenty years old. She works as a bartender in a cafe. Nasykat is not married and lives with parents. She needs a loan to pay her tuition contract. Zhyldyz is 25 years old. Zhyldyz is not married and works as a waitress in a cafe. At home she and her brother feed and sell cattle. Zhyldyz needs a loan to buy two calves. Olga is 52 years old. Olga works as a dishwasher in a cafe and has also recently opened a small grocery store. Olga wants to get a loan and buy two tons of coal and merchandise for the store. Turat is 21 years old. He is studying in a polytechnic university and also works as an operator at a gas station. Turat hopes to get a loan to pay his tuition fees.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy flour and meat for dumplings and noodles, and to pay for son's education

loans.name: K´alamarka Group

texts.es: El Banco de Emprendimiento KALAMARKA trabaja con nuestra Institución hace mas de dos años, este banco se caracteriza porque sus integrantes son 50% varones y 50% mujeres, las socias se dedican al comercio y venta de frutas, los socios la mayoria son transportistas.La señora Durán es una participante antigua y ocupa el cargo de presidenta con el prestamo a logrado diversificar y aumentar la producción de frutas que tiene en la localidad de Sapaqui, con este negocio a podido aumentar su capital y brindarles mejores condiciones de vida a su númerosa familia. la señora VICENTA, Es una nueva integrante y tiene a su cargo la secretaria, ella se dedica a la venta de CDs en las cuidades de La Paz y El Alto, con el prestamo a logrado traer por cantidad CDs,VCDs, mejorando de esta forma sus ingresos. El señor MOISES,esta en su 3er ciclo, actualmente ocupa el cargo de tesorero, tiene una familia compuesta por 4 miembros, es chofer propietario y con el prestamo a logrado realizar el mantenimiento de su movilidad, tiene pensado comprar varios repuestos como: llantas, pastillas, con el tiempo quiere ahorrar para comprarse otra movilidad, esta es su primera experiencia con Bancos de Emprendimiento lo que le a permitido ahorrar y mejorar sus ingresos para el y su familia.
texts.en:
The K’Alamarka Communal Bank has been working with our Institution for more than two years. The group consists of half men and half women. Most of the women buy and sell fruit, while the men are in the transportation sector.

Sra. Durán is a long-time member and currently serves as the Communal Bank president. Her loan will allow her to diversify and increase her inventory of fruit that she offers from her vending location in Sapaqui. She is requesting to increase her business capital so that she will be able to provide better living conditions for her large family.

Sra. Vicenta is a new member who currently serves as the Communal Bank secretary. She sells CDs in the cities of La Paz and El Alto. Her loan will be used to purchase CDs and VCDs in order to improve her earnings.

Sr. Moises, who is participating in his third loan cycle, serves as the Communal Bank treasurer. There are four members in his family. He is an independent driver and will use his loan to maintain his vehicle. Moises plans to purchase spare parts such as tires and switches. Over time he wants to save enough money to buy another vehicle. This is his first experience working with Communal Banks and having the opportunity to save and improve his family’s income.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: Lidia Arminda

texts.es: La Cliente Lidia, llegó a nustra institución por recomendación de una cliente buena y antigua, ella tiene su esposo que por el momento se fue a trabajar a la Rep. De Argentina en el rubro de la costura, es una persona joven que desde hace unos 6 años aproximadamente se dedica a esta actividad con un capital inicial que le dió su padre y con el dinero que le envía su esposo, fue ampliando la compra y venta de autos, aún no tine hijos, lo que ella en este momento esta priorizando la conclusión de su vivienda, la que se encuentra en la última fase, siendo una persona muy joven demuestra mucha inquietud, tenacidad y responsabilidad en las actividades que realiza.
texts.en:
A good and long-standing client of this institution recommended Lidia to us. Lidia's husband has gone to Argentina for the time being to work as a tailor. Lidia is a young person who has been a car retailer for the past 6 years thanks to initial capital she got from her father and with the funds her husband sends. She has enlarged her car retail business. She doesn't have any children yet, as a young person, she's restless, tenacious and responsible with all the tasks she sets up for herself. Currently, her first priority is to finish building her house, which is in its final construction phase.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital increase.

loans.name: Heang

texts.en:
P. is a 40-year-old local rice trader who has been engaged in this business for years. She is a widowed mother of five children. One of her children is a garment worker, two are married, and two attend school. 

P. buys mature rice in bulk from farmers to store in her inventory for a while. She sells them when the rice commands the highest price. P. does not have a way to commute to buy rice, so she decided to borrow a loan that she will use, along with her savings, to buy a motorbike for traveling needs.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to commute to buy rice

loans.name: Leonardo

texts.en:
Leonardo, the owner of A. Janitorial Services, has nine years of janitorial cleaning experience. Until recently, he worked for a large janitorial company, but in November of 2009 Leonardo made the commitment to strike out on his own. Between the demands of his new business and his part-time job at a golf course, he now works seven days a week, often from 7 a.m. to 9 p.m., but Leonardo is visibly enthusiastic about how things are developing. “I get great satisfaction being able to build my own company… this is something I am doing for my children,” he says.

Orphaned at the age of four, Leonardo was raised in Mexico City by his grandmother and uncle and the lessons they passed on inspired him to start his own business. “I saw the difference between people who had goals and a vision for the money they earned, and those who didn’t. My uncle was very good at business, and I could always look to him for advice.” With a strong determination to be his own boss, Leonardo makes time on top of his work schedule to take English lessons twice a week. It has been a great challenge, but he understands the need for good communication skills to help him attract new clients. 

With this loan Leonardo will be able to purchase a commercial-grade vacuum cleaner and the other new equipment that is necessary to continue his janitorial work at a local school, as well as expand the business. “This loan is a great help. With a little bit of investment I will be able to earn a lot more and provide a better future for my children.”

loans.use: To buy a commercial-grade vacuum cleaner and other janitorial equipment

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita M. is from the village of Poblacion, Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years old. Clarita is single and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Clarita owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as candies, sugar, salt, candies, Milo (cocoa mixture), milk sachets, shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Clarita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Clarita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Clarita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Clarita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used additional capital for her business. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Clarita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional capital for her business

loans.name: Teolith

texts.es:
La Sra. Teolith, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Valerosas II”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia y Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 57 años, es madre de 02 hijos, todos ya independientes.
Gracias a su anhelo y esfuerzo motivador Teolith emprendió su negocio de Costura,  lleva años  dedicándose a este rubro, poco a poco fue haciéndose conocida y ahora cuenta con  clientela sofisticada que a diario acuden a su casa a pedirle su servicio, nos cuenta que tiene bastante trabajo por la etapa escolar que se aproxima, también cose vestidos para damas, caballeros y niños, pantalones de vestir y mucho más, su negocio esta ubicado en su casa.
Nos cuenta que le va muy en sus costuras, trabaja con pedidos que con anticipación sus clientes le solicitan. A quienes les atiende con la amabilidad y el carisma que le caracteriza. 
Con este préstamo de S/. 2500.00 Nuevos Soles, comprará telas en metros, de diferentes especies y colores, instrumentos que utiliza como tijeras, hilos en carretes grande y de variados colores, agujas de coser y de maquina, alfileres, botones.
Teolith, sueña con tener su máquina de coser último modelo, se siente una mujer realizada, con más ganas de alcanzar y hacer realidad sus demás sueños. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por darle la oportunidad que siempre esperaba, tanto a ella como a otras mujeres para salir adelante.
texts.en:
Teolith, 57, is a member of the “Mujeres Valerosas II” (Valiant Women II) communal bank, which is located in Tarapoto district, San Martín province and department. She is married and has two children, both of whom are already independent. Thanks to her drive and motivating efforts, Teolith set up a sewing shop. She has been in this line of work for several years and has gradually become better known; she now has a sophisticated client base that come by her house daily to request her services. She tells us that she has quite a bit of work due to the approaching start of the new school term. She also makes clothing for women, men and children, dresses, dressy trousers, and much more; her business is located in her home. She tells us that she does well with her items; she works based on prior orders that her customers place with her. She tends to her customers with kindness and characteristic charisma. She will use this, 2500 new sol, loan to buy meters of fabric of assorted type and color, tools like scissors, large spools of thread in assorted colors, sewing needles and sewing machine needles, pins and buttons. Teolith dreams with having the latest model sewing machine. She is a fulfilled woman, with still more desire for making her dreams come true. She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for giving her the opportunity she always awaited as well as to other women who want to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy assorted fabric and thread.

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes N°3 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement  Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) comme son nom l’indique est un réseau de femmes qui s’activent  dans le commerce.  Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty Niakh l’actuel président du réseau. Cette présidente a eu cette idée  à l’issue d’une formation qu’elle avait bénéficiée  de l’ONG OXFAM à Thiès. Elle connait, ainsi, bien la gestion de groupe, entreprenariat …etc.  Les membres du réseau sont extrêmement dévoués et se rencontrent une fois par mois. Ainsi, après des frais d’adhésion au groupement, chaque membre est tenu de cotiser mensuellement 200 FCFA pour une caisse de solidarité.
Souhaitant se financer, elles décidèrent  d’adhérer à  U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que,  leur réseau se voit scinder en 19 sous groupes de 5 personnes  pour un meilleur profit des financements. Elles sollicitent pour une deuxième fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA par membre,  soit 500 000 FCFA par sous groupe afin de développer leurs diverses activités.
Cependant, les règlements sont versés à la présidente assistée par la trésorière du groupe, Madame Coumba Seck, pendant leurs réunions mensuelles et ces deux se chargent à leur tour de rembourser U-IMCEC. Ce réseau qui, dit la présidente, n’a qu’un seul et noble objectif : combattre la pauvreté dans les ménages. Actuellement, le réseau compte 19 sous groupes avec chacun une présidente et une trésorière.
Le sous groupe Femmes Commerçantes N°3 a comme présidente Madame Kanane Rose N.  âgé de 47 ans et mère de 3 enfants. Elle fait le commerce de légumes, huile de palme depuis 15 ans. Madame Khardiata O. âgée de 41 ans et trésorière du sous groupe vend des légumes depuis 12 ans au marché Grand Thiès. Les autres membres sont Madame Sokhna Touré Cissé qui vend des poissons séchés au marché, Madame Fatou L. vendeuse d’huile de palme et de gombo et Madame Fatou N.  qui vend du petit déjeuner dans sa maison.
texts.en:
As its name suggests, Femmes Commerçantes is a network of businesswomen, It is based at Grand Thiès and was created in 1992 by Mme Maty Niakh, its current president. She got the idea of forming the network after.benefiting from belonging to ONG OXFAM at Thiès, and was familiar with group organization and running a business. The members of the group are dedicated to what they do, and meet together once a month. Over and above membership dues, each of them pays 200 FCFA a month into a group operating fund. Looking for financing, they decided to join U-IMCEC. The network is divided into 19 subgroups of five people so that financing can be better handled. Each subgroup has its own president and treasurer. They now seek, for the second time, a loan of 100,000 FCFA per member or 500,000 FCFA for each subgroup, to grow their various activities. The members repay their loans to the president and the treasurer, Mme Coumba Seck. They, in turn, are responsible for repaying U-IMCEC. According to the president, the group has one praiseworthy objective -- to fight family poverty. Subgroup 3's president is Mme Kanane Rose N., 47 years old with three children. For 15 years she has been in the business of selling legumes and palm oil. Mme Khardiata O., 41 years old, is treasurer, and for 12 years has been selling legumes in the market at Grand Thiès. The other members are Mme Sokhna Touré Cissé, who sells dried fish in the market, Mme Fatou L., who sells palm oil and stew, and Mme Fatou N., who sells breakfast from her home.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies

loans.name: Estrellas Azules Group

texts.es:
Martha P. D. 50 años  se dedica a vender llaves, chapas y desarmadores, su hermano le había apoyado para que inicie esta actividad. Martha esta con su grupo hacer 6 meses, este sería su segundo préstamo. 
Con el préstamo elL. desea incrementar su mercadería comprando chapas al por mayor y acomodarlo poco  a poco en diferentes ferias D. L. ciudad D. El Alto, con estos ingresos elL. mantiene a sus 3 hijos ya que es viuda.
Martha también ha podido visitar al consultorio para hacerse L. prueba D. glicemia y el respectivo control D. peso y talL..
Las demás integrantes D. esta asociación tienen negocios como L. confección D. ropa, venta D. comida, atención D. teléfonos, venta D. repuestos, venta D. fruta y cereales.
texts.en:
Martha P., 50 years of age, dedicates herself to selling keys, switch plates and screwdrivers. Her brother supported her so she could start this activity. Martha has been with her group for 6 months, and this would be her second loan. She wants to use the loan to increase the amount of merchandise she sells, and buy switch plates at wholesale. She would like to market her merchandise in the different markets throughout the city of El Alto. With this income, she supports her 3 children, since she is a widow. Martha has also been able to have a consultation to have her glucose tested, and the respective control of weight and height. The remaining members of this association have businesses such as making clothes, selling food, providing telephone services, selling replacement parts, and fruit and cereal sales.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Day Break Mouth Open Group

texts.en:
Mary M. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Day Break Mouth Open. She is 34 years-old and married with four children who range from 4 to 20 years old. She also cares for four siblings.  Mary is a high school graduate but could not continue her education to college.

For eight years , Mary has been selling general goods such as soap, candles, and biscuits at the Du-Port road junction market in Paynesville, Liberia.  Mary sells quality products that are desired by customers in order to keep them returning.  Her goal and dream is to expand to a store and improve the living condition of her family.

She plan to use her 14,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 52,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to purchase more biscuits, soap, and candles.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Mary is holding the sign.

loans.use: To purchase more biscuits, soap, and candles.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The purchase of shoes and sandals

loans.name: Virgen Del Carmen De Qaqamarca Group

texts.es:
Las socias del Banco Comunal Virgen del Carmen D. Qaqamarca son D. la comunidad D. Qaqamarca, Distrito D. Ocros, Provincia D. Huamanga, las actividades principales D. la comunidad son la agricultura y ganadería.
Dolores es secretaria del Banco Comunal, Dolores es madre soltera y tiene 3 hijos 2 varones y 1 mujer, tiene una panadería en su casa, actividad que aprendió D. su familia que también se dedica al mismo negocio, sus productos los venD. en su comunidad con la ayuda D. sus hijos, los insumos los adquiere en la ciudad D. Ayacucho y también en su comunidad. Su préstamo será invertido en la compra D. harina para elaborar mas panes.
Los sueños D. Dolores son brindar una buena educación D. sus hijos, implementar su panadería con maquinarias modernas y comprar un carro para repartir sus productos a otras comunidades.
texts.en:
The members of the communal bank Virgen del Carmen D. Qaqamarca are from the Qaqamarca community, Ocros district, Huamanga province. The principal activities of the community are ranching and farming. Dolores is secretary of the communal bank. She is a single mother and has 3 children, 2 boys and a girl. She learned baking from her family and has a bakery in her house. She sells her products in the community with the help of her children. Supplies are acquired in the city of Ayacucho and also in her community. Her loan will be invested in flour, which will be used to bake more bread. Dolores's dreams are to give a good education to her children, to install modern machinery in her bakery, and to buy a car to distribute her products to other communities.

Translated from Spanish by Jeff Schell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of flour

loans.name: María Liliana

texts.es:
María Liliana tiene 21 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene dos hijos, vive en el distrito de Cura Mori, un distrito perteneciente a la provincia de Piura, en la región del mismo nombre. Se encuentra ubicado a tres horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se gana la vida desde hace tres años criando y vendiendo animales menores en corrales ubicados en la parte posterior de su domicilio, María cría ovejas  y cuando estas ya han alcanzado un buen punto de desarrollo las ofrece en venta a los negociantes que siempre visitan la zona en donde vive.

Adicionalmente también trabaja preparando y vendiendo chicha en su domicilio. La chicha es una bebida típica del país elaborada a base de harina de maíz. Se consume desde tiempos ancestrales, actualmente es consumida por los habitantes de zonas rurales en celebraciones y antes de empezar sus faenas, ya que creen que les da fuerza y vigor. 

María desea adquirir alimento balanceado para mejorar la alimentación de sus ovejas y venderlas a un mejor precio, asimismo desea adquirir insumos para seguir preparando chicha. Para lograr su objetivo ha solicitado por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 500 nuevos soles.

María es una mujer luchadora y que siempre da lo mejor se si para sacar adelante a sus hijos, su mayor anhelo es verlos convertidos en personas de bien y exitosas.
texts.en:
María Liliana is 21 years old and is the single mother of two children. She lives in the district of Cura Mori, in the Piura province of the Piura region. Cura Mori is located three hours away from the city of Chiclayo. María has earned a living for three years raising and selling small animals in pens located in the back of her home. She raises sheep and when they have reached a good size she sales them to buyers who frequently come to the area where she lives. She also works out of her home making and selling chicha. Chicha is a traditional beverage of the country produced from maize flour. Its been consumed since ancient times. Nowadays, it is consumed by inhabitants of rural areas during celebrations and before starting the day's labors, as they believe it gives them strength and energy. María wants to buy well-balanced feed to improve the diet of her sheep so that they can be sold at a better price. Also, she wants to buy ingredients to continue making chicha. To achieve her goal, she has requested her first loan from Edpyme Alternativa, in the amount of $200. María is a fighter and always gives her best to bring up her children. Her greatest desire is to see them become good and successful people.

Translated from Spanish by Tyson Shelley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase animal feed to better raise animals which are to be sold.

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic E., 32, is making sure that her family is provided with their daily needs. She is married to Armando E., a retired pensioner, and they are blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store where she also sells frozen meats and finger foods.

Marivic has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her variety store.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 9,000 PHP loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying groceries, toiletries and beverages.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to re-sell

loans.name: Kyenjojo Disabled, Kyenjojo Group

texts.en:
A transparent and very hardworking Robinah K., aged 50 years, is a married mother of eight children. She operates a retail shop, selling general merchandise for home use like plastics, basins, jerrycans, cups, salt, soap and more, from Rwamukora, Kyenjojo town. She started this business five years ago and at the end of every month, she is able to pocket profits to the tune of 200,000 Ugandan shillings. 

Her main drawback has been having a small amount of stock that cannot match the purchasing rate of the customers. Robinah is therefore seeking a loan that she figures will help her stock more goods that will satisfy the customers’ high demand and also transform her enterprise into a big enterprise as she looks at opening up more branches. 

Being very committed to the business with good customer care, she hopes to increase her sales revenue. This will bring about a transformation of her business and enable her to achieve a self-sustaining life and cater to her family requirements, especially fulfilling her dream of educating her children to higher levels.

Robinah K. appears at the top left corner in the small photo and she also appears in the big group photo.

loans.use: Purchase more stock of goods like basins, jerrycans, cups, salt and soap for her shop.

loans.name: Strong Brothers #2. Group

texts.en:
Alexander K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called "Strong Brothers #2." Alexander is a 20-year-old, single man who was only able to attend school through the 11th grade due to financial issues.

For 5 years, he has been selling milk and sugar on Water Street in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his portion (6,000 LRD) of the group loan (30,000 LRD, or $425) being sought to buy more cartons of milk and sugar. He describes himself as a respectful person, and he notes that his goal is to improve his business and to go back to school.

loans.use: To improve his business by purchasing additional cartons of milk and sugar

loans.name: Luz Marina

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal  “MANOS JUNTAS”; Este banco está situado en el distrito de Huanchac, perteneciente a la provincia y departamento del Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Luz;  Ella tiene 27 años de edad  y es soltera; La socia se dedica a la elaboración de mermeladas y también alterna sus actividades con la venta de cosméticos por catálogos, ella está ahorrando su dinero para poder hacer una empresa en el futuro y ser su propia jefa.  La socia solicita el préstamo para  invertir en la compra de insumos.

La socia agradece y valora el préstamo y del mismo modo se compromete a cumplir disciplinadamente con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The member belongs to the “Manos Juntas” (Hands Together) Communal Bank. This bank is situated in the Huanchac district, which belongs to the Cusco province and department. Luz is the member. She is 27 years old and single. She devotes herself to making marmalade. She also sells cosmetics by catalog, and she alternates these activities. She is saving her money to be able to have a company in the future and be her own boss. She is requesting a loan to buy supplies. She is grateful for and values the loan. She promises to be disciplined and make all of her payments on time. .

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies

loans.name: Irma Del Socorro

texts.es: Irma del Socorro M. posee en su hogar una pulpería desde hace 6 años, en su juventud ella trabajó de doméstica y de casi cualquier actividad u oportunidad económica que se le presentase, luego de dedicarse a la venta de nacatamales decidió probar suerte vendiendo meneítos, cigarros y chiverías; sin embargo se mantuvo así por mucho tiempo y fue con el primer crédito que adquirió que ella logró que su negocio empezara a crecer. Su meta para el futuro es que su negocio se haga aún más grande.
texts.en:
Irma del Socorro M. has had a grocery store in her home for the last 6 years. In her youth she was a domestic employee and worked at whatever activity or economic opportunity came her way. After selling nacatamales (Nicaraguan tamales popular as weekend fare) she decided to try her luck selling meneitos (cheese puffs), cigarettes and yoghurt snacks. For a long time this is how she remained but with the first loan she got her business started to grow. Her goal for the future is that her store be even larger.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise.

loans.name: Katende Development Group-Mpigi

texts.en:
It goes without saying and without any shadow of a doubt that the bedrock that will help any business grow and prosper is hard work and determination to succeed. M. Moses, who belongs to Katende Development group-Mpigi, knows this very well as he has experienced it first-hand in his commercial motorcycle business that he has operated for the last 4 years in Kasanje stage- Mpigi town. 

This business is one he began soon after he dropped out of school. He also does small-scale commercial farming. In a week he makes profits that add up to 50,000 shillings and with this loan he wants to pay the repair costs on his motorcycle.

loans.use: The repair costs on his motorcycle

loans.name: Cornelia

texts.en:
Cornelia O. is a widow who lives in Prk. Trece, Brgy. Tiniguiban, Puerto Princesa, Palawan. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: she runs a restaurant, rents out commercial space and is an authorized purified water distributor. She has three adult children. Cornelia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired to something better for her family. 

With the help of her past 11 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Cornelia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000 helped her raise her family's standard of living.  This time, for her 12th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500, which she intends to use to expand and improve her restaurant so that she can continue to save up in order to buy a motorcycle for business use. Cornelia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'Honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To provide additional working capital

loans.name: Oah

texts.en:
Oah S., 36, is a professional silk scarf weaver in the Takeo province. She has been in this business since 2003 and is able to make about $2 of profit per day. Each day, she usually produces two to five scarves and each scarf costs around $2. 

Her husband is in security, making $2 per day. This couple has three children and all of them are in school. 

Oah S. is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase more silk.

loans.use: To purchase more silk

loans.name: Luzvillian

texts.en:
Luzvillian M. is from the village of Tamil. She is 32 years old. Luzvillian is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $300 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Luzvillian joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Liloy-Tamil, Jose Dalman Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Florentina

texts.en:
Florentina T. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Maricalum, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  vegetable vending and farming. Her husband, Fausto Tabo-tabo, who is 58 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have seven children who are between 23 and 36 years old. 

Florentina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Florentina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 15,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,500, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for a new business so that she could continue to save up for future home repairs. 

Florentina T. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable) woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital for the farm

loans.name: Nilda's Group

texts.en:
Nilda Y. is from the village of Magsaysay Baliangao Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old. Nilda is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Millions.

Nilda is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Nilda owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a clothing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing general clothing services to local community members. Nilda has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Nilda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nilda is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics & materials. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Nilda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics & materials

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more fresh fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more ink pens, footballs, gloves, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase cloth and different kinds of threads.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma M. is from the village of New Look. She is 40 years old. Alma is married and has four school-aged children. 

To make a living, Alma owns and operates a business venture making and selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Alma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7,840 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2001, Alma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Alma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. 

Alma is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Alma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Amasimbi Group

texts.en:
Amasimbi group is comprised of 31 members. Grace is one of the members and she is the president of the group. Grace is 29 years old and has three children who are between the ages of 7 and 11. Grace's children are all in school and her husband is a motorcycle driver. Grace sells secondhand children's clothes and she is requesting a loan in order to buy more clothes.

Generally, all the group members have small businesses and most of them have shops in which they sell household items such as candles, sugar, etc. They are generally requesting a loan to reinvest in their businesses.

Grace is the one holding the ID, that's Rwandese's National ID. Some of the group members are missing in the photo because they could not make it to their meeting venue.

loans.use: Additional inventory of used clothing.

loans.name: Martha Irene

texts.es: Este cliente es originario de la comarca el tololar, actualmente se desempeña como maestra de primaria en el colegio Concepción de María de la comarca la Mora, es soltera sin hijos, convive con su mama, esta señora tiene 23 años de desempeñar dicha labor, ya que desde el año 2003 tiene financiamientos hasta la fecha, obteniendo mejores condiciones y nivel de vida, ya que la necesidad  inmediata es de embaldosar el piso para evitar la subida de humedad en tiempo de invierno para evitar problemas de salud principalmente por la mama quien es una señora de edad avanzada.
texts.en: This client is from Tololar district.  She currently works as an elementary school teacher in Concepción de María school, in Mora district.  She is single, doesn't have any children, and lives with her mom.  This lady has been working as a teacher for 23 years.  From 2003 to the present day she has had loans from CEPRODEL which have improved her living conditions and standard of living.  Her immediate need is to tile her floor to avoid the damp rising during the winter.  This will help avoid health problems, particularly for her mom who is an elderly lady.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand and gravel, and to pay for transportation and labor

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius, 52 years old, is married to Jublina, 45 years old. They have 2 children: 
•	Adrianus, 11 years old, who is in the fourth grade of elementary school, and 
•	Ovi, 5 years old, not at school yet. 

Julius is a farmer who always relies on the season in generating money. He utilizes a small plot of land that he has for farming and sells the crops after harvest. As the farming business is dependent on the season then there are times when Julius has to struggle in generating income for his family.  

With a small capital Julius initiated a new business besides farming by selling bananas and chickens. He usually buys bananas and chickens from his neighbors and sells them at Camplong Market and Inpres Market. 

Julius is thinking about improving his business. He is requesting a loan of IDR 10,000,000 from TLM. He intends to spend the loan on chickens and pigs to sell at the market. Julius hopes TLM will approve his application. He believes the loan will be a valuable support for his business in the future and for his family life.

loans.use: To purchase chickens and pigs to sell at the market.

loans.name: Dolgormaa,

texts.en: Dolgormaa, 49, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Govi-Altai Province in Mongolia. Her elder son works as a driver for a transportation company, and two younger daughters currently attend a college in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. She began retail trading of souvenirs, domestic appliances, and domestic wares at a local market in 2004. Her husband helps her with the business. She is trying to expand her business and increase her working capital. She is one of the reliable customers of our bank. She is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to enlarge her space and purchase more goods for her business.

loans.use: to enlarge her space and purchase more goods

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma C. is from Dipolog City. She is 50 years old, married, and has six adult children. Elma owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Elma has been involved in her business for over two years, and she earns approximately 4,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) a month from the business. She also maintains a rice field.

In 2010, Elma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation, and her ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP. Elma is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and pesticides for her rice field. This will be the third loan taken out by Elma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella is currently in a business of selling beans and maize flour. She is 28 years old and married with 2 children who both go to school.

Stella borrowed a loan to stock more beans and maize flour to sell. She hopes to expand in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: to stock more beans and maize flour to sell.

loans.name: Muqqadas' Group

texts.en:
Muqqadas lives in Kamoki, which is a small city in Punjab, Pakistan famous for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in a two-room brick house with her family in the area of Chajoki for the past eight years. She is a housewife as well as a working woman, Along with her household work, she does embroidery for her neighborhood clients. She is known as an expert in her work and provides good quality services to her clients. Her husband belongs to an agriculture profession. He works in his field and grows different seasonal crops to sell to his clients for profit. He works very hard all day in the field to fulfill the basic needs of the family. Muqqadas is the mother of two daughters and a five-month-old son. Both of her daughters are getting their education. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to buy fertilizers, seeds and pesticides for her husband who will use it on his field to get maximum output. Muqqadas is hopeful that the loan will enable her husband to get more profits from his business and improve her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticides

loans.name: Donatha

texts.en:
Donatha is 22 years old. She has 2 children who are aged 6 months and 2 years old. The elder child is in school. Her husband is a technician. 

Donatha is a tailor. She has done this business for 2 years and her business is going on well. She is requesting a loan to expand her business house, in which she does her tailoring. She plans to open up a general store with the profits that she plans to make. This way, she will have two businesses in order to make more profits.

loans.use: to expand her business house.

loans.name: Lucia Genoveva

texts.es:
Lucia  de 25 años de edad, es soltero, vive con sus padres en su casa, cuenta con todos los servicios básicos, ubicada en  la provincia de Chiclayo que pertenece al departamento de Lambayeque.  Esta zona se caracteriza por la actividad agrícola, ganadera y turismo.

Desde hace unos 3 años aproximadamente Lucia se ha dedicado a la venta de abarrotes (productos que se utilizan diariamente como: leche, arroz, aceite, azúcar, papel higiénico, atún, huevos, etc), su negocio lo ha colocado en el mercado de la zona donde vive, con las ganancias por la venta de sus productos  trata de cubrir  todos sus gastos y mejorar su nivel de vida.

Para poder  ampliar su negocio a solicitado un crédito a Edpyme Alternativa  de 2000 nuevos soles para comprar más mercaderías, con el único ideal de que su negocio crezca y tenga más productos para ofrecerles a sus clientes y para cubrir su préstamo.  Lucia es una persona responsable, dedicada y trabajadora que se preocupa por tener mejoras personales y para con sus padres.
texts.en:
Lucia is 25 years old, single, and lives at her parents’ house in Chiclayo Province, Department of Lambayeque. They receive all of the basic services. This area is known for its businesses in the agriculture, livestock, and tourism sectors.

Lucia has been selling groceries for approximately three years. The products she sells on a daily basis include milk, rice, oil, sugar, toilet paper, tuna, eggs, and other items. Her business is located at the market in the same district where she lives. The earnings from the sale of her products help to cover all of her expenses and improve her standard of living.

In order to expand her business, Lucia is requesting a loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 2000 PEN so that she can buy more merchandise. This is the only way for her to grow her business and have more products to offer to her customers. As a result, she will be able to cover her loan.

Lucia is a responsible, dedicated, and hardworking person. She is concerned about her self-development and looking after her parents.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for her store.

loans.name: America Rosa

texts.es: La señora America se dedica a la venta de artículos de limpieza, entre otros productos, realiza esta labor en una calle muy transitada de la ciudad, américa es casada, su esposo trabaja como vendedor ambulante vendiendo control remoto para televisores, y  con ello ayuda en los ingresos familiares, ambos son muy trabajadores, tiene casa propia, los desafios que enfrenta america y su esposo, es la competencia que hay en zona, el dinero que esta solicitando, es para mejoramiento de vivienda comprar ladrillos,cemento,arenas,para  construir un cuarto mas en su casa, america como toda mujer luchadora tiene mucho sueños uno de ellos es tener un local propio donde ofrecer sus producto , america esta muy agradecida con la confianza que se le esta brindando.
texts.en:
Señora America works selling cleaning supplies, among other products.  She does this work in a busy street in the city.  America is married, and her husband works as a street vendor selling remote controls for televisions, thereby helping with income for the family.  Both are hard workers, and they have their own home.  The challenge facing America and her husband is the competition that exists in the area.  

The money being requested is for home improvement.  It is to buy bricks, cement, and sand to build another room in their home.  America, like every struggling woman, has many dreams.  One of them is to have a separate space where she can offer her products.  America is very grateful for the confidence that is being shown in her.

loans.use: to improve her home, buying cement sand bricks among other things, for construction of a room in her home.

loans.name: Ratha

texts.en: Ratha (in the photo) is a garment worker and her husband, Savuth, is a farmer. They have been married since 2008 and have one young son. They live in a village about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Ratha is asking for a loan of $1,000 to assists her husband’s farming business by buying a motorized hand tiller.

loans.use: To buy a motorized hand tiller.

loans.name: Maria Adilia

texts.es: Maria Adilia una joven de 24 años de edad, casada y con un hijo de apenas seis meses de edad. Vive en una comunidad llamada Cerro Grande ubicada en Yalaguina departamento de Madriz con su familia. Hace mucho tiempo como toda mujer emprendedora le toco ir a buscar fortuna fuera de su comunidad hacia la ciudad de managua donde estuvo trabajando de doméstica, pero al pasar el tiempo regresó a su comunidad donde se caso y en conjunto con su esposo dicidieron con un pequeño capital poner una venta, donde en la actualidad la tienen un poco más amplia. Solicitó su préstamo para compra de granos básicos y otros productos para surtir su venta. En un futuro desea mejorar su casa y comprar bienes del hogar para darle un mejor de vida a su hijo.
texts.en: Maria Adilia, 24, is married and has a six-month-old son.  She lives with her family in a community called Cerro Grande which is located in Yalaguina, in the department of Madriz.  Some time ago, like all women entrepreneurs, she had to seek her fortune outside of her community and went to the city of Managua where whe was a domestic employee.  After a while she returned to her community and got married.  She and her husband decided to use a small amount of capital to set up a store, which is now a bit larger.  She has requested a loan to buy basic grains and other grocery items.  In the future she would like to improve her house and buy household goods to improve her son's lifestyle.

loans.use: To buy basic grains (rice, beans, etc.)

loans.name: Luka

texts.en: Luka is an ambitious 41-year-old businessman. He is married and blessed with a seven-year-old child. To provide for his family, for the last two years he has been operating a barber shop. Previously, he used to engage in cattle farming. He wants in the next five years to have excelled in his business and his dream is to be financially stable. He is requesting a loan of 9,000 Kenya shillings to buy a solar lamp. Thanks to Faulu Kenya, he is now able to make critical decisions.

loans.use: to buy a solar lamp

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora

texts.es: Maria Auxiliadora tiene su negocio que es una pulpería. Hace más de 8 años que tiene este negocio. Esta no es la primera vez que realiza financiamientos con la ayuda de ellos ha podido salir adelante y mantener a su familia. A sus 53 años ha tenido una gran experiencia en su actividad, tiene 1 hijo a su cargo por lo que tiene que proporcionarle los ingresos necesarios para sobrevivir. el crédito que está solicitando es para la compra de golosinas, grano básicos, refrescos pan y detergentes.
texts.en: Maria Auxiliadora’s business is a general store. She has had this business for more than 8 years. This is not the first time she has received funding. With financing she has been able to get by and support her family. At age 53 she has had a great experience with her business.  She has one dependent child for whom she has to earn needed income to survive. The loan she is requesting will be used to purchase sweets, bulk grains, beverages, bread and detergent.

loans.use: to buy sweets, bulk grains, beverages, bread and detergent.

loans.name: Robina's Group

texts.en:
Robina is married and her husband is a driver by profession. He drives a vehicle called a pickup and provides loading services to his clients and pick and drop off facilities to different school children.
 
Robina has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will repair his vehicle's engine, which will allow him to provide better quality transport services to his customers and earn good profits. He has been in this profession for many years and Robina is very hopeful that an investment will help him save his business assets and increase his profits
.  
Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Robina.

loans.use: To repair his pickup truck

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort is a widow who has two children. After completing senior high school 15 years ago, she has been selling wakye (rice and beans) to people in the village of Jukwa. The loan money will help Comfort to buy beans, rice, tomatoes, pepper to make wakye and to support her family, especially as she is the sole breadwinner. 

Wakye is a traditional rice dish in Ghana. To prepare wakye, she gets her beans, rice, and colored leaves from the market. She cooks the beans until they become tender and adds the colored leaves to give them a reddish color. Then she adds the rice to the bean mixture. She cooks the rice and beans until they become tender to eat.

Wakye is normally eaten with macaroni, wele (cow skin), gari, salad with pepper sauce, tomatoes sauce, fish, or meat.

loans.use: to buy beans, rice, tomatoes, pepper to make wakye

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine lives in Uganda. She is widowed with 4 children and all go to school. She has no additional family members. She lives in her own house and the family has access to piped water and electricity. Her monthly expenses include rent for her business premises, utility bills and school fees.

Christine sells secondhand shoes. She has been in business for the last 5 years. She sells her products from a shop that she rents. She works 7 days a week. She has requested for a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO to buy more bales of secondhand shoes. Christine generates additional income through selling bags. Her major business challenges include transportation, thieves and seasonality. 

Her goal of inspiration is to build rental houses and rental rooms, and also to expand her business so that she sells on a wholesale basis.

loans.use: to buy more bales of secondhand shoes

loans.name: Francisca Merta

texts.es:
Francisca de 53 años, una mujer trabajadora y honrada que ha sabido como ganarse la vida honradamente.
Su negocio es venta de bebidas como: aguas, colas, etc.

 Es madre soltera, tiene tres hijos ya todos son mayores de edad.
Ella solicita este préstamo para ampliar y mejorar e incrementar su negocio el dinero restante lo quiere para la compra de materiales de construcción.

El sueño de ella es que su casa este terminada ante de que ella fallezca.
texts.en: Francisca, 53, is a hardworking, honest woman who has known how to earn a living honorably.  She sells beverages like water, soft-drinks, etc.  She’s a single mother and has three children who are all now adults.  She asks for the loan to expand, improve and enlarge her business.  She will use any money left over to buy building materials and supplies.  Her dream is to finish building her house before she dies.

loans.use: to buy beverages and bags of ice.

loans.name: Ernestina

texts.en:
Ernestina is 24 years of age and married with one child. Ernestina owns & operates a business venture, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community.  She has 1 year of experience in this business. Ernestina needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2011, Ernestina joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Ernestina's 1st loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hoji

texts.ru: Хочи занимается растениеводством. Ему 62 года. У него шестеро детей. Он разведен. Его дети живут вместе с ним. Он более 17 лет выращивает овощи. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений, топлива и семян лука.
texts.en: Hoji cultivates crops. He is 62 years old, and has six children. He is divorced. His children live with him. He has grown vegetables for more than 17 years. He is applying for credit to purchase mineral fertilizers, fuel and onion seeds.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fertilizer, fuel, and onion seeds

loans.name: Irma Del Socorro

texts.es:
Irma, continua trabajando, pero ya no en su negocio propio de su pulperia, pues su inversion se vino a bajo, cuando comenzo a dar creditos, el cual no pagaron cerrando la venta, en donde busco un trabajo fijo. Pues son tres hijos a quien dar estudios, alimentacion entre otros gastos, ya que no cuenta con la ayuda del papa de los niños.
Lleva, casi el año laborando, en servicios domestico, pero su objetivo es seguir mejorando su pequeña casa, con este nuevo financiamiento, hara un muro  lateral, reguardando mas su propiedad, dando a sus hijos seguridad.
texts.en:
Irma is continuing to work, but no longer in her own general store business.  This is because her investment collapsed when she started to extend credit which wasn't repaid, causing the store to close. So she looked for a regular job. 

She has three children to educate and feed, as well as other expenses, as she doesn't have help from the children's father. She has been working as a domestic for almost a year, but her goal is to keep improving her small house. With this new loan, she will have a side wall built, providing more protection for her property, and keeping her children safe.

loans.use: To build a side wall to protect her property.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy replacement parts for her husband’s vehicle.

loans.name: Maimoaga

texts.en:
Maimoaga is a 36-year-old woman living in the town of Sataua Tai.  She is married and has 4 school-aged children. Maimoaga owns and operates a business making and selling fried foods in the local community.  Maimoaga has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 1,200 WST a month from it.

In 2010, Maimoaga joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,000 WST from SPBD, which was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.  Maimoaga is now requesting her second loan of 1,000 WST which will be used to invest in expanding the business. Maimoaga plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to pay her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: to purchase mutton flaps, chicken leg quarters and french fries

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Em is 61 years-old and married. She has two children and lives with them and her husband in Ho Chi Minh City. Her husband helps her to manage a general store.

Em runs a store at her house that sells many kinds of food, snacks, instant noodles, milk, fruit-juice bottles, and shampoo for the people in her community. She started this business seven years ago.

Em would like to take a loan to buy a large quantity of products to sell to her customers. She hopes that through the loan she will be able to generate a higher income and save money to further expand her business.

loans.use: to buy a large quantity of products such as food and beverages to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Giri Puteri Group

texts.en: Ni Made is borrowing a new loan from MUK to increase her business, she has a plan to buy six piglets and use the rest of the loan for feed. During this period she will maintain pigs for pig rolls (roast suckling pigs). These kinds of pigs are maintained for two months and then sold. This business really helps with her family's income. Ni Made has a dream to become the biggest pig seller in her village.

loans.use: To buy 6 piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Celina

texts.en: Celina is 35 years old with no children. She has had a business selling food in a hotel (restaurant) in Yei, South Sudan for five years. Celina is requesting this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase beans and rice. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase beans and rice

loans.name: Jukunay

texts.ru: Жукунай 56 лет, вдова, воспитала семерых детей. Жукунай начала свой бизнес в животноводстве еще 20 лет назад, стартовав с суммы 3,000 сом (KGS). Благодаря упорному труду Жукунай, ее хозяйство приносит около 5,000 сом (KGS) в месяц от продажи молочных и мясных продуктов. Также, Жукунай обрабатывает 3,12 га земли, где выращивает картошку и ячмень. Летом, Жукунай с семьей выезжает на пастбища («жайлоо») горного озера Сон-Кол, где разбивает «юрту» - национальное войлочное жилище – где могут остановится туристы и приезжие гости. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса в животноводстве, Жукунай обратилась в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 120,000 сом (KGS) на покупку 3 бычков и 10 овец. Доходы Жукунай планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение поголовья скота.
texts.en: Jukunay is 56 years old, a widow and raised seven children.  She started her business in animal husbandry 20 years ago with an initial sum of 3,000 som (KGS).  Thanks to her persistent work, Jukunay's business yields about 5,000 som (KGS) per month from sales of milk and meat products.  She also works on 3.12 hectares of land, where she grows potatoes and barley.  In the summer, Jukunay and her family travel to the pastures ("jailoo") of the mountain lake Son-Kol, where they set up a "yurt" - national felt house - where tourists and visiting guests can stop.  In order to further develop her animal husbandry business, Jukunay requested a loan in the sum of 120,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum and Partners" company to purchase three bulls and ten sheep.  She plans to invest the profits into further increasing livestock headcount.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Gloria Concepcion

texts.es:
La señora Gloria, tiene 41 años de edad, esta casada, tiene 2 hijos, ella vive con su familia en una Aldea, sus hijos le acompañan en su negocio y su casa y su esposo se dedica a su taller de Carpintería en el departamento de Francisco Morazán.
El negocio de Doña Gloria  es la venta de golosinas como tacos, enchiladas, pastelitos de carne, catrachas, pollo frito, carne asada, pescado frito, refrescos, jugos, agua, entre otros productos.
Doña Gloria esta solicitando la cantidad de 8,000.00 lempiras para la compra de productos para elaborar golosinas y comida como Carnes, Pescado, Harina, Manteca, Verduras y condimentos.
Con el apoyo de este tipo de créditos comprara productos para abastecer su negocio y lograr incrementar el nivel de sus ingresos y aumentar sus clientes.
Entre los planes de Doña Gloria esta expandir su negocio, ya que le gustaría acondicionar más su negocio.


San Lorenzo, Honduras - Marzo 2012
texts.en:
Gloria is 41 years old, married and has two children.  She lives with her family in a village.  Her children accompany her at work and at home and her husband works in his carpentry shop in Francisco Morazán Department.

Gloria’s business is selling snacks like tacos, enchiladas, meat pies, “catrachas” {fried corn tortilla with beans, “chismol” [chopped tomatoes, onion and cilantro with lemon and spices] sauce, cilantro marinated tomatoes, red onion and grated dry cheese}, fried chicken, grilled meat, fried fish, soft-drinks, juice and water, among other products.

Gloria is asking for the amount of 8000 lempiras to buy ingredients to make snacks and food like meats, fish, flour, lard, vegetables and condiments.  With support from this type of loan she will buy products to stock her business and increase her income level and number of customers.   Among Gloria’s plans is to expand the business since she’d like to better equip it.

San Lorenzo, Honduras – March, 2012

loans.use: to buy meat, fish, flour, lard, vegetables and condiments.

loans.name: Demetrio

texts.es: Demetrio, de 48 años está casado con Victoria quien es madre de sus 2 hijos y que viven con el en su casa construida a base de adobe. Demetrio se dedica a la agricultura en sus terrenos de cultivo donde tiene diversos productos rentables de su zona como plantas de cacao, café y árboles frutales. Desempeña está actividad desde hace más de 21 años. Siempre cuenta con el apoyo de su esposa y en tiempos de cosecha contrata a trabajadores del lugar  para agilizar sus cosechas y venderlo a los compradores de la zona. Los terrenos de cultivo que tiene actualmente son el fruto de su trabajo. Desea trabajar para brindarles a sus hijos apoyo para que estudien y se conviertan en  buenos profesionales. Es el segundo préstamo que solicita a su entidad financiera y espera contar con la confianza necesaria para seguir adelante, además se compromete a pagar sus cuotas de manera puntual. En esta oportunidad desea contar con 1,000 nuevos soles para la compra de abono orgánico y así fertilizar sus plantaciones.

loans.use: Compra de abono orgánico.

loans.name: Fouad's Group

texts.en:
Fouad is a member of this group from Iraq. He is 27 years old, married and has two children. His family depends on his income for their living. Fouad started working as a decoration  eight years ago with little money. As his family expenses increased, so did the responsibility and burden to increase his income. 
He is requesting this youth loan to purchase jepson boards, so he would be able to compete and attract more customers and meet their needs. With this loan he is confident that he will increase his income and support his family's needs. 
The story of Fouad and his business is just one of the many examples of Izdiharona for economic development clients .

loans.use: A portion of Fouad's Group $ 2,400 loan is to purchase jepson boards.

loans.name: Danaya I Group

texts.fr:
Les  10 membres du groupe  DANAYA I  sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 31 ans, 4 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à MANA, un des villages de OUELESSEBOUGOU 2ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur septième  prêt de campagne avec l’institution.
La spéculation cultivée est  l’arachide, le riz et le mil avec   FATOUMATA, 1ère personne  assise de la droite vers la gauche  sur la photo.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants, des semences et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  1,5 hectare. 
La production est vendue au niveau du marche, après la récolte à une clientèle composée de revendeurs et de consommateurs. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 120.000FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aider aussi son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.

loans.use: Frais de labour, achat d’intrants et  de semence

loans.name: Hernando Jesús

texts.es: Hernando de 26 años es un joven soltero que decidió dedicarse al negocio familiar de venta de pasteles de arroz, él reside en un barrio de Soledad y desde el año 2014, se encuentra elaborando comida típica de Región con excelentes resultados. Sus ventas las realiza por encargos los días viernes, sábados, domingos y festivos, estos días su producción inicia a las 6 a.m., para que sus clientes puedan degustar de los exquisitos pasteles a las 12 del mediodía.  Hernando realizó una solicitud de crédito, un credikiva, oportunidad para vincularse a la vida financiera a través de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo para comprar víveres necesarios para la preparación de sus pasteles como arroz, aceite, carnes, vegetales y aderezos. Esta financiación le dará la oportunidad de mejorar sus ventas y aprovechar la temporada decembrina en la que se consumen con frecuencia pasteles de arroz.

loans.use: comprar víveres necesarios para la preparación de sus pasteles como arroz, aceite, carnes, vegetales y aderezos

loans.name: Erika Roció

texts.en:
Rocio lives in Escobedo in the province of Neuvo Leon, is mother to two small children aged 10 and 2 years, and her husband is a welder but his work is often unsteady and his salary is not enough to cover the family expenses. Rocio found a way to help support her family, she started her won business selling shoes and clothing. Slowly her business grew and now she requests a loan of $200 to buy more inventory. She needs this loan to meet the high demand for her articles during this holiday season.

Rocio wants to give her children and education and a better quality of life. You can help her and her family. They thank you for your generosity and your kindness. She will repay the loan within 3 to 6 months.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Rocio vive en Escobedo Nuevo León, es madre de 2 pequeños de 10 y 2 años de edad, su esposo es soldador, sin embargo su trabajo es inestable y su salario no le permite cubrir con todos los gastos de la familia. Por esta razón Rocio encontró la forma de apoyar a su esposo comenzando su propio negocio, este consiste en la venta de zapatos y ropa. Actualmente su negocio a crecido poco a poco, pero necesita de un apoyo por $200 DLLS para comprar mercancía que le permita enfrentar el incremento de demanda debido a esta temporada navideña.

Rocio desea ofrecer a sus hijos estudios y una mejor calidad de vida; tu puedes apoyarla y ayudar a su familia, ellos agradecen tu generosidad y cariño. En un término de 3-6 meses ella planea regresar el préstamo. ¡Apóyalos!

loans.use: purchase merchandise

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en:
Ludmila thoroughly enjoys meeting the needs of many women for quality, stylish footwear. With the help of her son she manages two sales kiosks at the Angolenko market in Zaporoshie where she sells a variety of shoes and boots. Her extensive 15 years of experience in this area of retail have given her much credibility as well as popularity among buyers and her fellow merchants. Ludmila’s biggest desire is to efficiently provide for her two sons who she was left to raise on her own. Through her business venture she has been able to provide an education for her older son. Now she would like to provide a good education for her younger son. Ludmila is even willing to downsize her home if necessary and move from a house to an apartment in order to be more conservative with finances. Ludmila recognizes that spring is a very active sales time when many women look to purchase a new pair of shoes. To meet this demand, she needs to exchange her winter inventory for a spring one. She has requested a loan for $750 that will allow her to buy a spring collection of shoes in bulk in order to provide a nice selection during this busy season.

Людмила з радістю займається продажем якісного та стильного жіночого взуття, задовольняючи потреби покупців. Її син допомагає їй з торгівлею, вони мають дві торгові точки на ринку Анголенка в Запоріжжі, продають туфлі та чоботи. Людмила торгує вже 15 років. За цей період вона змогла заробити гарну репутацію серед колег-підприємців, в неї з’явилося багато покупців. Понад усе Людмила прагне дбати про своїх двох синів, яких виховує самостійно. Завдяки власному бізнесу вона змогла дати своєму старшому сину можливість навчатися в університеті. Зараз її наступна мета – дати таку можливість і молодшому. Заради цього Людмила навіть готова зменшити житлоплощу та переїхати з власного будинку у квартиру, щоб зекономити необхідні для цього кошти. Людмила розуміє, що весняний сезон – це період активної торгівлі, взуття продається дуже гарно. Отже, вона прагне розширити асортимент товару напередодні весняного сезону. Для цього Людмила просить про позику в 750 доларів, яка надасть їй можливість закупити багато взуття за оптовими цінами та задовольнити попит покупців.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Penina

texts.en:
Penina and her husband were unemployed and had depended on their relatives for survival.  Their three children went to live with relatives because Penina and her husband had no way of supporting them.  Penina lives in a small Samoan village where there are no opportunities for formal employment.  Thus, Penina joined SPBD.  

She knew that she had to find a way to capitalize on her talents to bring in income for her family.  She decided to start a sewing business, and she used an initial loan from SPBD to purchase a sewing machine.  Penina’s business is going well and loan funds will allow her to purchase fabrics and needed supplies to ensure that she can meet her customers’ demands for consistent, high-quality product.

loans.use: Purchase fabrics and sewing supplies

loans.name: Gbamble

texts.en:
Gbamble L. Z. is a very dynamic 46-year-old woman with 2 children. She sells various fruits and vegetable in Yopougon (Northern suburb of Abidjan ) open market. She lives in Yopougon with her family. She contributes significantly to her family's living expenses with revenues from her micro business. Her husband retired from public administration years ago.

She joined the AE&I microcredit program in January, 2005 and has performed very well since then. She requests the loan to purchase more goods which certainly will help her increase her profits and improve her family's living conditions. She is ambitious and committed to her job.

loans.use: Gbamble Lou Zamble will use the loan to purchase goods in bulk.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is married with six children and has been in the tailoring business for 10 years. He makes gent’s suits and currently employs two people. He is the only one who makes gentlemen's suits for weddings in Kayunga, therefore he has market for his suits, but needs more money to be able to meet the growing demand. He therefore plans to buy new sewing machine and materials.

loans.use: Ibrahim wants to buy a new sewing machine and materials for making suits for gents.

loans.name: Yaver

texts.en: Yaver G. is an Internally Displaced Person from Khojavend city of Nagorno-Karabakh, western Azerbaijan. He settled with his wife and two children in Beylagan city in 1992. Yaver is a taxi driver. He needs a $700 loan to repair his car.

loans.use: Yaver would like to repair his car for his taxi business.

loans.name: Um

texts.en: Mrs. Um Y., age 54, works selling foodstuffs and provisions, earning only $1/day of profit. Her husband, age 56, works as a farmer, making about $1 each day. They have seven children, two who are mechanics, two who are students, and three who are married and live separately. She is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase piglets to raise and resell in the market for a profit. Her husband is pictured in the photo as she was not available at the time.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and resell in the market for a profit.

loans.name: Marhabo

texts.en:
A. Marhabo is 33 years old. She is married and has two children.

She was been selling clothes for women for  8 years in the local market of Istaravshan city. Her husband used to help her in the business, but he recently had to leave for Russia for a job. Twice a month Marhabo goes to purchase new goods to sell. Thus she is trying to have the new goods in order to keep up with the demand of her clients. Her business is the only source of income for her family. So, Marhabo is working hard to generate efficient profits to ensure that she can support her family.  

Marhabo has been provided with loans by IMON for 2 years. For the entire period of time she has shown herself as an accurate client having a positive credit history. Today Marhabo requests 1000.00 US Dollars. Part of the loan she is planning to spend to purchase  new clothing for women to sell and the rest to pay the rent for the trading place in the market. Marhabo thanks everyone for support and promises to pay the loan in 12 months.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing for women to sell and pay the rent for the trading place

loans.name: Preciosa

texts.pt:
Preciosa wants to use this money to purchase firewood for the production of bricks. Preciosa is married and the mother of 4 children. Her husband works as a clerk in a government institution. His salary is approximately $150. Preciosa, besides making bricks for sale also raises chickens. Her 4 children are all in school.
